Sam was great, and if you need a tuk tuk driver while you are there, he's the man. Kevin and Heather

Very good middleman to introduce one to Cambodian arts and crafts. We got our introduction to 3 Cambodian art and crafts usiing Backstreet Academy: Bokator self defence, crossbow making and iron pencil sketching. An English-speaking staff member met us at an appointed place to bring us to each activity. Where the artist, e.g. the iron-sketching specialist is not able to communicate exactly what to do, a translator is there for us. Every activity was booked online, with payment instructions clearly stated. Well organised.For Bokator, the self defence class, the Grandmaster is able to speak English, so no translator was provided. My son and I had so much fun we plan to do it again when we next visit Siem Reap. For the iron pencil sketching, it is not an easy task for a 10 year old. As a result, the bulk of the sketching of the picture chosen by my daughter was completed by the artist himself. Nonetheless, my daughter enjoyed herself as she learnt how to handle an iron rod and the novelty of drawing a picture through burning a material. As for the crossbow making, it was an eye opener for a city kid to watch the craftsman shape the bow and the materials they used. It was like watching DIscovery Channel live, for him.Overall it was good fun for the family to do activities together and the children enjoyed these activities more than touring the sights.

Copper Wire Bracelet making with Bel and Chanra. My two children and I spent a lovely morning with Bel and Chanra at the KILT (Khmer Independent Life Team) homestead learning how to make copper wire bracelets. The money they raise from selling and teaching people to make jewellery helps them to support and educate 8 adults and 12 children who live in the homestead. Bel himself was badly injured as a 7 year old by a landmine. We took some snacks that we shared and the children played football together. A great activity - worthwhile on many levels...with lovely bracelets to take home too! We booked online the day before through Backstreet Academy. Booking was simple and fast with clear instructions for the day.

Highly recommended. We took the stonecarving class on our last day of the trip and spent an afternoon in the Academy. The teacher was very sophisticated, knowledgeable and patient in teaching us to finish our first stone carving pieces. It was an interesting experience to do after visiting the Angkor Wat. We enjoyed it very much.

Annoyed . I turned up at the address given on TripAdvisor wanting to make a booking for the following day only to be told that I had to make the booking through the Internet via there website. This should be stated on TripAdvisor so as to not waste people's time driving to your address given out

Great local experience! Must-do!. We did the Fishing and Hunting Tour and the Camboidan Cocktail class. Both of them are really well organized. All hosts were very welcoming and showed us a lot of their local specialties. The Hunting tour in the woods were an eye-opener, and offers a good peek into the local village life. The Cocktail class was a sweet and nice treat after dinner where we got to taste local spices and use them in our tasty refreshing cocktails. We wish we could have more time to join the other activities offered by Backstreet Academy. A must-do in Siem Reap!

Best thing we did in Siem Reap, excellent family time!. We did palm leaf box weaving with Sopheap - four of us, two children aged 7 and 8. We had a great time and came away with professional looking boxes that we made (with some help of course!). For me, it was the best time spent so far with the kids, they had a fabulous time learning a new skill and in two and a half hours I didn't hear "I'm bored" once! Amazing!! It did look complicated to begin with but once we started it we got the hang of it and Sopheap and her friends were happy to help us along! The arts and crafts on display were lovely and I would much rather support the local people of Siem Reap rather than buy mass produced goods that are probably made outside Cambodia. All very reasonably priced as well. Thanks for a great afternoon out :)

Bokator and ultimate food tour. My girlfriend and I did 2 activities through this privately run organisation. Did the ultimate foodies tour which was brilliant. Really good to cook up a big lunch (go hungry!) in Mrs Lam's front garden. Food tour later on was also interesting, turns out frog is actually fairly tasty. We also did the Bokator lesson for an hour. This was one of the highlights of our trip and definitely recommend if you want to do something different. Small annoyance was being met by the backstreet representative at a hotel then advised to pay a tuk tuk to get 200 metres down the road where the lesson was. Then the lesson was interrupted 10 minutes in to be told to make our own way home and we never saw the backstreet guy again. It's $20 per person per lesson but only $10 goes to the grandmaster and the rest to Backstreet. Best to book directly for this one.

A fun, interesting and well organised experience! . A friend and I found backstreet academy whilst visiting Siem Reap. We had never heard of the organisation before but once we had we found lots of things on their site that looked like fun! We settled for the Cement bags workshop. When we arrived we were greeted by two warm and welcoming Cambodian women. They were so helpful and patient and supported us throughout the afternoon in making our bags! We chose a material and style and left as two happy customers. I would highly recommend this workshop and look forward to trying backstreet academy in the future! Thanks for a great afternoon.

Amazing food tour!. We did a food tour with Sam, and it was amazing! We were taken to a few different local markets and got to sample all sorts of amazing food, from fresh fruit to delicious fried rice cakes to stuffed frog to tarantulas and crickets (took me a good half an hour to get over my fear and sample those). Sam was extremely accommodating to the endless barrage of questions we had and whenever we asked about a fruit/food we had never seen before he would just buy it and let us sample it! Great way to see Siem Reap off the beaten track and see where the locals go. Most of the places that Sam took us to we were the only non-locals there! Overall a great experience and one of the best things I did in Siem Reap!

Stone carving. Stone carving is not as simple as u think. just join the class n u will appreciate the temple carvings. our teacher Poy Khet is a very good instructor. Leave things to him when u mess things up with the carving. he can do wonders.

Brilliant Fun. We booked in to do the stone carving, wanting to try something different. What a fabulous experience. We carved a candle holder each, and the work and skill required is something to be tried. A great few hours with a fantastic souvenir to take home, all hand made by yourself. Highly recommended

Thanks Sam!!!!. We did the local street food evening tour with Sam the Man. Sam showed us a side of Siem Reap I'm sure that most foreigners never see. We visited three markets, tried fresh sugar cane juice, I ate my first dragon fruit as well! Try the dip (a fruit)! At the second market we gorged ourselves on fruit and we saw a lot of raw fish and pork being prepared to be sold which was we opening. It's fasinating to see where your food comes from. At the third market, we ate frog stuffed with spices and pork which was mouth watering. And we ate crickets and tarantula! It sounds scary but it was the tastiest thing I ate all evening, and Sam had a good laugh at it. We made him try the spider as well! He was pleasant company and was very accommodating to our every need. If you're feeling adventurous, take a food tour with Sam! Thanks again my friend.

Great way to spend a few hours. My 11 year old daughter and I did a copper bracelet course with Backstreet Academy. We had a great time, trainers were very helpful and patient. It took about 1 1/2 hours to complete and we came home with a really nice keepsake.
Great experience!. I've loved all of the classes I did through Backstreet; the instructors were always very nice and patient and the translators were always so personable and informative.

Great food tour . We did the Local Street Food Evening Tour with Soy Kosal. Highly recommend this tour for those who want to try real Cambodian food. We tasted food from local markets and stalls (Kosal selected stalls were the food was prepared cleanly). Kosal was very accommodating and delayed the start time to suit us. Kosal was very knowledgeable and friendly. Our 12 year old really enjoyed it too.

Thats why you come here. This is why you come to Siem Reap,to see these magnificent structures.Absolutely mind blowing,you will take hundreds of photos trying to catch the reality,but the photos still dont show the true feeling you experience when your there live.We came in September i was prepared dor some rain,but the weather has been wonderful,we had 2 showers nothing to uncomfortable.It was humid and hot but not as bad/hot and humid as it can get.The crowds no problem this time of year.I believe we came here at the perfect time.We didnt bother coming for sunset or sunrise but I can image it would be spectacular.We will certainly visit here again in the future,still many more temples to explore.

Cement bag making 😁. Had so much fun today making my elephant cement bag! The ladies aiding my sewing skills (laughable to begin with) were so kind and patient!! It was a lovely experience to do with girls on a chill day from the temples!! Highly recommend this!!

Knife Making. Only tried one class and it was the knife making class and we loved it. It was so authentic. It was a little shed and the instructor did not speak any English. There was an interpreter who was really great. He even bought us some coconuts as he could tell that we were very hot and sweaty on our walk over to the pickup point. We even got to take home the knives we made! Definitely recommend doing it.

Experiencing local culture. We joined 2 activities offered by Backstreet Academy, namely the Cambodian cuisine cooking class and Bokator (Cambodian boxing). Our translator Kert was helpful and friendly. He was definitely a big help in translating what our host, Ohm Lam was trying to communicate to us. We are truly grateful for Ohm as she opened up her kitchen to us and taught us how to cook Cambodian cuisine.A representative, Ve from Backstreet Academy also came to Ohm's house midway to ensure that all was good. It's small acts like this that made our trip so much more memorable. Ve also followed us to our next activity which was the Bokator class. He helped us to take some pics to capture our attempts to become the next Manny Pacquiao, haha.. All in all, Backstreet Academy is definitely something you should consider for your trip in Siem Reap!

True Cambodian Experiences! . In August 2015 my partner and I took two courses in Siem Reap. The first was a two-day overnight homestay at a working Cambodian farm. During our stay we made our own slingshots and learnt to fire them, made and set traps in the jungle, went fishing in a pond for our dinner, heard traditional Khmer music played by our host, went rice farming and helped a little with some cooking. The second was a flute making course where we made our own traditional Khmer flutes out of bamboo. For both courses the hosts were friendly, informative, helpful and professional. Our courses were real hands-on experiences and we enjoyed learning new skills and about the Cambodian lifestyle. We would recommend Backstreet Academy to anyone who is visiting this part of Asia and wants to learn more about the life and traditions of a different culture.

A must visit project!. This is a great project went with my sons to make handmade crossbows. It was really good fun.We were introduced to Mr. Mien who comes from a tribe who used to make these bows for hunting.My youngest (8 years old) said " it was amazing! Really good fun. It was quite difficult to make but it was worth the effort as it was so much fun shooting them. Really looking forward to showing my friends back home."The project run other activities that were fun. Check out their website. If crossbowsis not your thing then some of the other workshops will be!!

Rice farmers for a day....and so much more! Wonderful day with a Cambodian family!. We signed up for a day of rice farming and a Cambodian cooking class for the same day. Our host was Mr. Mean Nhean and his family, a 30 minute motorcycle ride away from Siem Reap. We (two young adults, 19 and 21, and Mom) were picked up by 3 motorcycles which were conducted by the son, the son-in-law and the guide Gaad, very safe drivers. Welcomed by the entire family of Mr. Nhean. Fitted us with huge hats for sun protection before we went to the rice fields. Had so much fun working in the fields, picking rice plants, ploughing (had a wonderful bonding moment with the family while laughing our heads off at our attempts on plouging), planting rice. Then went fishing in the pond. No rods, just getting into the water fully dressed with Gaad and the son of the family, using a net for fishing. Great fund and successful. Then back to the house, cooked with the daughter who showed us how to fix coconut soup with lots of veggies, chicken and pork, then a famous Cambodian dish called Amok fish, then a banana coconut dessert. All three of us worked with her, carefully watched by the entire family, lots of laughing on both sides. Mother-in-law watching carefully! We chopped veggies and chicken, made coconut flakes from a coconut just taken off the tree, wrapped fish into banana leaves, cooked bananas and a lot more. We shared the meal with the entire family which was an honor for us. After lunch, the Dad played music for us on this traditional Cambodian instrument with 2 strings, the son playing a drum. What a wondrful day! We felt honored that the family let us get a glimpse of what their life is like, let us sit at their table (or rather on it, Cambodian style). Our gude Gaad was incredible. He explained everything along the way and was the interpretor for the day as well. Lots of fun. Made us laugh a lot. With a lot of thank you's and bows we gave our good-byes and were taken back to Siem Reap. What a wonderful day that truly connected us with Cambodia. We received VIP treatment and felt humbled and happy.

Wonderful experience--see another side of Cambodia. We had a fantastic time at Backstreet doing a crossbow workshop with my two sons, ages 7 and 8. They will never forget this. Allow plenty of time--this took over 3 hours. Also allow time to shop at Angkor Handicraft Association's market, which is in the same building.

Simply amazing. Firstly I want to be very clear, this was an amazing experience that I would not have missed for anything!After falling in love with the cement bags at the markets we decided to do the half day course and make our own. On arrival we got to choose our own design with some members of our group going for the cool satchels, but me electing for the safer lower end of the skill scale with the shopping bag. Even after thoroughly testing the patience of our teachers they never once stopped smiling, encouraging or, in my case, assisting. And in the end I managed to complete my simple shopping bag (complete with hidden pockets and zippered lining).What I did discover is that their is no way I would be able to sustain my family in this industry and that those skilled artisans who do this work day in and day out are amazing. Don't take the soft option and buy these from the markets, do yourself a favour and make a memory of your own and you might just learn a thing or two along the way.

AMAZING! I can't say enough positive things about it!. I booked 2 in one day (cement bag and the copper bracelet with Bel). What an amazing experience from start to finish. A long day and hot as it's summer in Cambodia, but wow, what fun, and what a great break from the tourist stuff! It was great to learn some crafts (despite being dreadful at them!) while integrating with local people. Everyone was so kind and patient, and I left both places with two wonderful pieces. At the cement bag one I made a toiletries kit (thanks to the help of the staff there!). and my copper bracelet came out fantastic (also thanks to staff assistance...they even gave me a gift, a copper ring to match my bracelet)I can't wait to book another Backstreet Academy activity when I am traveling again! Thanks for an experience that I will never forget!Sorry I was so terrible at sewing my cement bag :)

bug cooking class by friendly locals. loved this - 2 young Cambodian students, in a small alley yard, showing us how to season and cook a selection of insects - crickets, worms and tarantulas!!! - in oil in a huge wok over a wood stove on the ground - and eat them. Our hosts were charming, friendly and knowledgable,explaining how people turned to eating bugs in the famine of the 1970s and bugs are now part of 'traditional' cuisine. Surprisingly tasty (crickets are a bit like crisps) and informative, and fun - and giving money to the local community.

Great lecturer.. We went for Stone Carving Class, our lecturer Khet is very very good, he is very careful person, we r very tired of stone carving but when we complete our work it look fabulous, thanks alot khet, our unforgettable experience ever in Cambodia.

family fun. We were booking the cement-bag-course the night before but the people at the Backstreet Academy made it work. The place is great to watch and the making of the bags was lots of fun for the whole family. Very nice and helpful people. We can strongly recommend this course. The kids are still proud of their bags, many thanks!

You MUST visit !!. A small, out of the way place where stallholders off 100% Authenticated Khmer products. Shop here for your souvenirs, gifts and that stunning woven piece of silk and you will supporting local village women & men trying their hardest to make a living out of their craft. Unlike some items on offer at Phsar Chas, the tourist market, you WILL NOT be buying a mass produced factor product from Thailand or China. Visit AHA and you will see the difference, purchase one or more of their beautiful 'Made in Cambodia" products and you will MAKE a difference !

Blacksmithing. My girlfriend and I did the blacksmithing course offered through backstreet academy and we really enjoyed it. He gives you a piece of rio and guides you through the process of flattening it into a blade. Most of the finer work is done by him or an assistant and a good thing too as we would have mucked it up. Maybe bring along a set of ear plugs as the grinder can be a bit noisy. Great experience though, something I've always wanted to try.
Unique and Local Fun Activities. Great resource for unique local activities in Siem Reap. We did the Escape the Room challenge with our family of 6, kids aged 8,10 and 14, it was great.

Absolutely lovely!. Me and my boyfriend did a spoon painting course with Backstreet Academy, and we both loved it. The instructor was super supportive, But didn't intrude unless we asked him too, so we got to make work that was truly our own. And some of the other instructors even came over and admired our finished work and chatted with us - it was a super friendly, really laid back, just generally lovely atmosphere. AND For only $20 it was a great way to take home something that was legitimately unique.

A highlight of our trip. When our plans for part of our visit in Siem Reap fell through, we got on line to figure out what to do. We immediately happened upon BackStreet Academy and signed up for the cooking class with Long Lam. Everyone from our great interpreter to the BackStreet Academy coordinator, Samon was so friendly and helpful, and we made an amazing Cambodian feast. We had such a good time that we signed up for two more classes the next day - Knife Making and Iron Pencil Sketching. Both were extremely unique and loads of fun. With Knife making, the blacksmiths to the majority of the work, but you get to pound a piece of rebar into a proper knife and do a bit of the finishing as well. The Iron Pencil sketching is not easy, but the key is to pick a simple design. While Bunhok definitely helps a lot, if you have patience and pick a simple design (or if you're just really artistic and coordinated), you will walk away with an amazing and completely unique souvenir that you made yourself (mostly). Samon was very accommodating, facilitating our last minute requests and spending time with us at each of the classes. Having the chance to learn from and engage with locals was truly enjoyable and made us happy to have had our original plans fall through.

Nice first day!. My boyfriend and I decided to take the cooking class right upon our arrival to Siem Reap - it was a fabulous idea! The teacher was friendly and her interpreter was energetic and enthusiastic. The class was a good introduction for us to the food, culture and market for our trip. It was also great timing because it allowed us to see sunset at the temples! This was our first class with backstreet academy, but I would absolutely do another!

Worthwhile experience!. We enjoyed the cooking class and it was nice to be invited into a home setting. The only improvement would have been written recipes in varying languages to take away. You work on various elements of dishes rather than completing them all so it is difficult to do prep and watch.Our guide was particularly good and a very talented artist, we were able to see some of his work.

Fear Factor is a must. So I completed the Fear Factor class on my own one afternoon. Ate fried crickets, silk worms and tarantulas. The kicker was definitely the tarantula wine though. Not for the weak-stomached. The course is well put together though and Backstreet does an amazing job.

Great fun...and a souvenir! Wish we had found Backstreet sooner. Had a great time at the copper bracelet-making session in Siam Reap. The site was a small silversmith's shop and they were great to work with - very patient with our neophyte's efforts. It was very informative and we took away two great bracelets...and a new appreciation for just how meticulous and time-consuming this craft really is. Thank you!

Snap, crackle, pop...fried crickets. My family thoroughly enjoyed this experience. The crickets, tarantulas and silk worms were fun to cook and sample...loved visiting with the cooks son...he was a cutie and put us at ease as he munched on a tarantula with us:)

Local Street Food with Kosal Soy. Kosal is a fantastic host. He is friendly and patient and speaks English fluently. This is a truly authentic tour of the local markets and street food scene. It is not for the faint-heated as the places Kosal takes you to are busy, dusty, bustling and crowded; and definitely not tourist traps. They are local as local can be. The included foods are interesting and delicious and plentiful.It's a pity that we did the tour on arrival, when we were feeling tired and queasy from our long flight. We would have enjoyed it so much more (and eaten more) had we arranged the tour for Day 3 or 4 of our holiday.Keep up the great work, Kosal!

Stone carving with a professional. My friend and I spent 3 hours with a local craftsman trying our best to create a stone carved candle holder. It was very difficult but gave us a real appreciation for the wonderful carvings around all the temples.

A good experience. I took the "Making palmleaf boxes course". My teacher was late but very nice. She could not speak any english which complicated my learning. An interpreter was present during the entire course. She was also very nice and caring.

A cool little 'aside' the whole family enjoyed. We signed up through the Backstreet academy who offer a huge range of local activities and act as the 'middle men' to connect travellers with local artisans etc. we signed up to do the copper bracelet making. Now we are comprised of 2 completely craft free adults, 2 teen boys and a 9 year old girl. That's a tough gig for a craft workshop but we all had a great time and emerged with very respectably attractive copper bracelets although some with more hand-made authenticity than others :). Great option to provide a change of pace to temple tours, pub street and markets. An interesting and fun morning without being exhausting or overly expensive. Thoroughly recommended. Suspect kids under about 8 might struggle a little but there is plenty of help on hand to help them along.
We had fun during the pottery class!. We enjoyed the pottery classes even though it was pretty challenging. Thank you to our instructor and his assistance for the great knowledge and time.

Real taste of Cambodian life!. We joined the fishing experience with Soy Kosal and it gave us a real taste of the local life! We started off visiting a local market which was further off from the touristy hotspots to buy two big fish in case we couldn't fish any, and then headed to a village near Tonle Sap (20-30min ride away from town). We then got down to business and learnt how to fish with a fishing net, which was very interesting but tough. The water was very low so we only found some small fish, but we also found small crabs! After an hour or so, Koy and the driver set up a fire with charcoal and wood and we grilled all the fish and crab. We talked about Cambodian daily life, and knew much more about Siem Reap as a touristy town but also the culture and religion and life of an ordinary Cambodian. Soy and the driver were very nice and spoke excellent English! It was a highlight of our trip, and through Backstreet Academy, the money goes to the local people whilst we could also get an authentic local experience. Would definitely recommend these rural tours!

One-of-a-kind experience!. We booked the iron pencil sketching class with Mr Bun Hak, assisted by Wey the facilitator. This was such a different and unique experience for all three of us as we have never done anything like this before. Wey told us that Bun Hak created this art 8 years ago by accident, so to speak. You'd have to book a class with them to know more ;) It was quite hard at first but we managed to finish our sketches with their unending help. The atmosphere was chilled and relaxed, we shared experiences and stories (even favorite songs) with each other. Mr Bun Hak is such a cool person and I love his taste in music haha! We highly recommend booking any courses offered by Backstreet Academy to anyone who is looking for something else to do in Siem Reap besides visiting temples. Thank you Backstreet Academy for such a memorable experience!

A fun morning!. We spent a morning making wooden flutes with a craftsman and a translator (who were both very friendly and helpful). The tools were more difficult to master than they looked but we both managed to make an approximation of a flute and both flutes are playable (we were also given the flute that the flute-make had made to demonstrate the techniques). We did around 90% ourselves - the flutes were finished-off for us with a very sharp knife which we were happy not to handle! It took around 2-3 hours in total. We would recommend this experience to other travellers and tourists; we had fun, learnt something about Cambodian culture, made a souvenir to take home and we were left with the feeling that we contributed some funds to locals who might otherwise struggle to engage with tourists.

Unforgettable experience. My friends and I had the opportunity to experience iron pencil sketching with Mr Bun Hak. He is the founder and only person who knows about this art in cambodia. He is a very talented man and i am honoured to have met him. He was very patient with us and helped us along the way. It was an unforgettable experience and the highlight of my trip to Siem Reap. And again i couldnt help but mention how friendly and hospitable the people of Siem Reap was during our entire stay.

Cooking course, Great fun, great food. I did the cooking course on my last day. On of the best things I did on holiday.We started in the market with Sophia and Madam Lon Lam, possibly one of the best double acts of all time, real insight into the food as Madam Lam threw a sub standard catfish back in disgust and then onto Madams home where the cooking began outside. Lots of dishes, raw beef salad, red chicken curry, fish amok and sticky sweet rice with custard more like a blancmange with coconut milk and duck eggs. Sophia was a great teacher, English very good, funny and charming and her and Madam Lam sparked off each other very well.Great to spend time in someone's home as people came and went and then of course a sit down to fine food , so much better than any of the restaurant food. Sophie was cool and gave me a lift back to the hotel on her Moto with a bag of grub for my "madam" . As always charming real,people who have a story to tell and who can give you a great insight into the day to day life of Cambodia, as well as teaching you to cook lovely grub.. Thank you Madam Lam and Sophia, it was great and a privilege to meet you both.

Street food tour with Soy Kosal. Loved it!!!! So good to get away from tourist areas and learn about what cambodians really eat. Kosal is just lovely and full of information. All the food he offers is delicious - and there is plenty of it.A very unique experience. Highly recommended.

Interesting and educational!. We ended up doing 4 Backstreet Academy classes and enjoyed them all! Would highly recommend this to get a close up experience with local people and learn traditional crafts!

Dont miss this experience - cookery class with Mrs Long Lam & Sophea. We are just back from this fantastic experience. Watching Mrs Long Lam work her way discerningly round the market was great fun, we toddled behind her as willing slaves carrying her purchases as she picked, prodded and bargained her way to the best produce.Back at her home in the large outdoor kitchen, Sophea - Who speaks excellent english, showed her masterful cookery skills under the watchful eye of Mrs Lam with some occasional guidance. Sophea was very patience and encouraging, taking the time to explain and even google each ingredient, the relationship she has with mrs Lam is a delight too, they are like family and treat you as such too. We have so far eaten in some of the best restaurants in Phnom Penh and Siem Reap but the fish amok we cooked with them was streets ahead in flavour and freshness to anything we have had before. This was a true highlight, Mrs Lam & Sophea make a winning team

Something to do other than temples. Took my wife to the copper wire bracelet making class. We ended up making them in a couple's house, who gave very good instruction and were really helpful. Enjoyed the experience a lot.

Copper bracelets. My sister, cousin and I spent my cousin's birthday making copper bracelets. I have worn mine several times. The instructor offered great assistance. My only issue is that they had no copper products to buy. I would have loved to bought a few more as presents for people.

Variety of classes. We took 4 classes:Copper wire bracelet making: 5/5, we went to an orphanage run by mr bel (who had stepped on a landmine) and his wife. We spent about an hour and a half making beautiful copper wire bracelets and rings and got nice souvenirs.Knife making: 4/5, we hammered hot steel to make knives and polished it with a metal grinder afterwards. A bit hot (since we were near the furnace), but how many people can say they made their own knives? We only did about 25% of the work, though.Cocktail class: 4/5, we mixed ginger, khafir leaves and rice paddies to make interesting and surprisingly refreshing cocktails. Enjoyable.Foodie vespa tour: 5/5, we rode vespas to the local market to inspect ingredients, then to a street outside of thr city where we tasted crickets, beetles, snails and cocoons, as well as various local fruits. After that we had frog barbecue and grilled stomachs, then beef with red ants and fried duck tongues (i didn't even know that ducks had tongues that big!). We ended in the simbai rice- wine shop where we had a wine tasting of the different infused soirits. A bit more expensive than the other classes, though.

Wonderful rice farming with Local. After 2 day of temple tour, I went to join the rice farming tour at local farm that located about 30 km from Siem Reap town. It was wonderful experience, i had learned a lot about how Cambodian people growing rice, vegetable and their life style with a beautiful green village. Local food was wonderful, we love the test of fresh grilled chicken with traditional source that was great! Highly recommending to everyone who love to travel and exploring the authentic local's life.

Budding Artists!. Booked a bracelet making course for 3 of us before arriving in Siem Reap. Thought we would be going to the central location as per the pictures on the website to be taught by the lady who we had emailed. Turned out, she was out of town and our course was not taught at the central location. Was a little disappointed in this however the gentleman who did teach us had a table set up for us , all the equipment needed to make the bracelets and he was very experienced in jewellery making, so all turned out well. A representative from Backstreet Academy came to the site partway thru the course and was very helpful, taking pictures for us etc. All in all it was a wonderful experience and we all have a beautiful bracelets to show for our efforts. Would recommend

Great time fishing with Soy Kosal. We had Soy Kosal as our guide and he took us to a pond near his hometown. It was really good fun and interesting to see how the local people live and what they do to survive.He was very patient and took a lot of time to teach us how to prepare the net and then throw it to catch fish. It was really good fun and we both really enjoyed our time. It was also the low season so we caught a lot of small fish. I'm sure in the wet season there will be a lot of bigger fish to catch. We also went to the local market to buy some fish and we grilled it up beside the pond (you won't get hungry). We also bbq the rest of the smaller fish to eat for lunch. There is a lot of cool water and beer so just bring yourself sunscreen and a hat.Really enjoyed this - it's something different to the temples in Siem Reap. Thanks Soy!

Wonderful cooking class in Siem Reap. We did the cooking class with Long Lam in Siem Reap and it was fantastic! Really a great way to see local life and learn a local dish. We have already made the beef salad back in Sydney for friends and they were blown away! The translator Sophia was wonderful as well and a very good cook herself.

Interesting. The host was patient and thoughtful in teaching us. The stone carving activity made us appreciate the carving on Angkor Wat. We had fun, learn something new and got to bring a beautiful hand craft stone souvenir.

Help the people and book through Backstreet. You can book direct for tours or through Backstreet and pay a little extra, but the extra helps people of Cambodia and the knowledge and information given by the operators of each tour is worth it. I met some wonderful people and shown more wonderful things that I wouldn't have if tried myself.

Best Part of our Trip to Siem Reap. Hands down, our best memory of the trip. We did two classes - kick boxing and the copper wire bracelet making class. Both were unique and fun in their own way.We had the same tour guide for the whole day and she helped make the experience memorable at the pick up location. She picked us up on her scooter and the three of us drove off (which was an experience in itself) to first class - kickboxing.The kickboxing instructors were fun and worked us hard. The class was in the middle of a local neighborhood so we felt like we were off the tourist path. The bracelet making class was one of my most memorable experiences in my Asia travels (and I have gone many places as I lived in Shanghai for 3 years). The instructor is a land mind victim who is really making a difference in his community. After having his mother die, his father abandon him, putting himself through college, and being rejected from a government desk job because of his disability he decided to use his frustration for good - and create a NGO that focuses on providing life skills to kids with disabilities from land mines. Hence his bracelet making course. Not only is his organization an inspiration, the class itself was fun and the jewelry we made was beautiful - I get compliments every time I wear it!Do one of these classes. It will be the story you tell your friends about your trip. Trust me.

Ceramic Painting Class. Arrived for the ceramic painting class and were provided with some paint, brushes and 6 of the same mugs to paint. We were given very limited colours (brown, dark orange, off white) and therefore we asked for more paints to be provided - green, blue, pink, red, yellow etc. We were told by the host then that they could not supply these colours as they had run out of them. For me this is unacceptable and if they are putting on an activity and charging for it they should have the materials required to allow you to create the designs you want. My wife wanted to paint a flower but couldn't as there isn't a lot you can do without green, red, yellow etc. We left after about 40 mins.The next day we received our mugs and the quality of them was terrible. Prior to them being fired they were glazed however the person glazing has clearly put on too much and therefore all of the colours have run into each other making the designs a total mess. We ended up just chucking the mugs in the bin.Avoid this activity - there are much better ones to do!

A great way to make your own souvenirs. We did the coconut carving class, and it was everything we expected and more. My fiancée and I were the only ones there with the instructor and a translator. Even when working one-on-one with the instructor, the language barrier was not an issue in figuring out what to do. They took us step-by step through making three coconut keychains. We got to choose two of the designs and the third was an Ankor Wat design. They turned out great (with a little help)! It was great to have a unique experience and self-made souvenirs to take home with us. Although I can only speak to this class, I highly recommend looking into the Backstreet Academy classes as a great alternative to the usual tourist activities.

Morning Martial arts (Cambodian Boxing). A very enjoyable martial arts session with Mork Samrith. Backstreet Academy provided a translator to help communicate. You will go to the backstreet to find Mork's hidden gym, and get to learn Bokator techniques along side of his young students. My girlfriend did not want to participate and decided to watch and laugh....a lot.Definitely a unique experience for anyone interested in Martial Arts and has a bit of time to sweat a lot. lol.

Do it. We did the bag making and the bangle making. The bag making was great, the women were fantastic and very patient do it as its not something you will do. The bangle making though was over priced and we actually didn't do much so disappointed with that

A way to see more than the typical tourist stuff. I did the copper wire bracelet workshop and the apsara dance workshop. Both were fun and I came away with a lovely bracelet I (mostly!) made by myself. I was the only participant at both - the apsara dance might have been better with more people and felt a little long with just the one of me. A great idea and a nice way to see more than just the temples in Siem Reap. Great value. Lovely people.

Best local experience ever! . My boyfriend and I participated in 4 courses, stone carving, knife making, iron pencil sketching and copper wire bracelets. All of them were unique experiences and worth all the money! The stone carving and iron pencil sketching were located at the local handicraft association, and here you could look and buy a lot of different things made from local artists. The knife making was located at a local blacksmith, who didn't speak English, but was in the best mood anyway, he just laughed all the time and it was contagious! The bracelet making was located at another organization helping victims from land mines make a living. If the host didn't speak good English, a translator was provided. We got to know the hosts and the country pretty well, and it was a really different and personal experience. If your looking for something to do that is not too touristy, do this!

Delightful way to spend a morning. My sister and I did wire copper bangle making workshop. Bel and his wife were an absolute delight and their story is so inspiration and KILT (http://kiltjewellery.weebly.com/) is such a worthwhile cause. We chose quite simple bracelets so the workshop only lasted an hour (which suited us in the heat) but the real highlight was meeting a local family, getting a small insight into their lives and knowing you are supporting local artisans PLUS you get a bracket to boot... I think this would be great for kids as well.

Cambodian Cocktails. My wife and I did the Cambodian Cocktail course, what a brilliant way to while away and hours or so. We chatted with our host as she showed us how to mix amazing drinks using fresh herbs and spices. The setting is very chilled out, away from the hustle and bustle that is Pub Street. Highly recommend booking this, we might just have to go back while her for another drink..

Great experiences. So this is not really about the skill being taught, more about the opportunity to support locals who are trying to make a living from their craft - the benefit is you get to do this is learn about the craft, and the artisan, and often their family and life. We did two classes (copper bangle making and tyre bag making) and loved both of them and the whole experience they provided. Would be great for anyone of any age and you come away feeling enrichened by the experience. Would really encourage you to give it a go - will be definitely doing more of these in the future.

One hour not worth $30.. I signed up my daughter and me for the 2-hour Apsara dance class. Though the instructor was pleasant, she gave no introduction or explanations, or even talked to us, so the translator did all the talking. We just had to copy her movements repeatedly, but with her back to us, we couldn't see her hand movements. We took several breaks, then she was done after an hour. The translator, also pleasant, said some people take a full two hours to learn the routine (as if we'd learned it!), as an excuse for why the class was finished so early. My daughter preferred playing the musical instrument, and I would have liked learning anything about the culture and history of Apsara dance, besides just mirroring the instructor's movements.

Beautiful Bangle Making. My wife and i were looking for an interactive experience with local Cambodians. Backstreet Acadamy delivered. The three hour class was lead by the nephew of a local artisan. We were impressed with the eagerness of the instructor and his drive to show us how to make something we would be proud of. The shop owner also took time to help us properly form the bracelet. Everyone at the shop was helpful and friendly. It is great to support the local economy is a direct and interesting way. I am sure that you will get as much out of the experience as you are willing to put in. HAVE FUN!

Excellent authentic experience with the locals. We learnt copper bracelet making with the teacher and his wife at their Home which is also the association of landmines victims. Our three hour class took place under the mango tree. Though hot, it was an unforgettable experience of not only learning the bracelet making skills but also learning inside stories of the local people. With Cambodia new year arriving, we talked about the ways of celebration, and How children would give respect by serving the baths to their Parents.

Great fun! . Three of us did the cement bags workshop today and loved it! Arranged very easily by emailing the night before. We are now the proud owners of our very own handmade tote bags; who needs the night market?! The instructions were easy to follow even for someone who has never been near a sewing machine in 20 years, and the whole session was fun and relaxed. Great experience, thanks guys :) we also bought lots of goodies from AHA!

Cement Bags. Partner and I did the Cement Bags course one afternoon. Where else can you get a Cambodian recycled bag (lined and all) that you have made yourself! - I can't think of a better souvenir. Very friendly instructors, We went on a day when the power was out in town (quite common in hot season) so I got to experience the old fashioned manual sewing machines - quite a laugh and work out, my partner got lucky as power came back on for him so he used electric sewing machine. Neither of us had touched a sewing machine since back in school home education days. Very impressed with finished product.Highly recommend for both men and women of all ages! choose the bag you want to make, the cement bag material (elephant, eagles, fish etc..) and support local artists. Wish we had more time to experience all the other wonderful courses they provide ( I walked around and saw some great work there) Thanks for the great experience!

Wonderful way to meet locals. The favourite activity of our 8 day stay in Siem Reap! My 14 yr. old daughter and I took the copper wire bracelet class. We found this very out of the way location easily and Muy Sua Bel and his wife were ready and waiting to help us with our bracelets. They have several samples to decide from and then we sat under a mango tree and worked away under their guidance. Since we were the only 2, it took just over 2 hours - with me needing lots of help - to produce really great bracelets. It is a very relaxing pace sitting outside and talking with our hosts whose English was certainly good enough for conversation. The family lives in the compound with several other families and there were lots of children playing around. It was a wonderful chance to talk about and observe ordinary life. They have more jewelry to purchase if you want (no hard sales pitch) DEFINITELY recommend this class and organization.

Catching and eating fish. Our guide was Samon, who was extremely friendly and helpful. He took us to a smaller village outside Siem Reap where we got to go to an outside market and try some different foods. We then sat on a truck bed and went out to a pond, where we were able to try net fishing. I was able to catch a few fish, as well as some others. The fishing was very enjoyable. Our main contact there was Kosal, who was great at helping us learn to fish as well as prepare and cook the meal. We got to eat some delicious Cambodian dishes, all cooked with the fish we caught that day. Afterwards, we were able to ride some boats around the lake and relax. Overall, a great experience that I highly recommend!

Wonderful Experience! Samon was the best!. I thought Backstreet Academy was a great way to meet local people as well as take home a wonderful souvenir. I did both the Iron Pencil class with Bunhak, who is an amazing artist and can help anyone to make a beautiful scene (no art experience necessary). I then did the copper bracelets where the owner of one of the best silver shops in Siem Reap helps you to construct your bracelet! Samon was my translator for the day and he was amazing. He was so kind and made my experience in Siem Reap unforgettable.

Apsara Dance - fun!. I was traveling alone and decided to sign up for the Apsara dance class. I've had a few years of dance training in ballet and ballroom, so I thought it would be an easy and fun way to learn about Cambodian culture. It was and it wasn't. It was surely fun and interesting, but the dance was harder than I expected! It's good the instructor gave me breaks and the translator helped me take plenty of photos to take home!

Bokator - Backstreet Academy. Mork was our instructor for the Bokator backstreet academy class. We warmed up for about 10 min, then we were taught basic Bokator punching, blocking and counter moves. Next we moved on to kick and punch combinations followed by blocks and leg holds. We finished up with a quick core workout for cooldown. Mork himself was an experienced (National Bokator champion) and patient instructor, and we had help from a backstreet academy employee to translate when needed. The workout itself is moderate if you're in shape but may be difficult if you're not. For me, I can finally carry out my lifelong dream of rising to UFC greatness,defeating Anderson Silva in an underground cage match, and becoming the undisputed world pound-for-pound Bokator champion.

Excellent . The cement bag activity was great fun! The ladies were very friendly. Great concept. Would have done some of the other activities if we had more time. Amazingly talented artists here, some of the work in the shop is amazing. Highly recommend. Thanks!

Awesome.. I signed up for a copper bracelet making class. The guy who ran it was very kind and patient (took me a while to get the hang of it!). They book you in for 3 hours but about 1.5hrs of this is after you've finished your part and they do all the tough stuff with blow torches and hammers etc. First in best dressed so I'd recommend finishing first! Or if you're with a big group, bring snacks :P A lot of fun to make your own souvenir.

Intimate Experience -Up Close and Personal. My husband and I spent a couple of days visiting temples in Siem Reap and we spent time on Pub Street and Night Market but we had some extra time so we decided to sign up for a jewelry making workshop.We never expected that this would be one of the high points of our trip but it was. We were the only people to sign up for the class that morning. We meet or interpreter at the specified hotel and then walked to our workshop and met our instructor. I had not realized that he was a landmine victim having lost his leg when he was only 7. He some how survived the horrendous injuries to both his leg and stomach and is now married, with a baby, and he has taught himself a number of crafts/skills and shares them with others in these workshops. We spent 3 hous sitting under a mango tree coiling, wrapping, and ever so slowly, making our respective bracelets. He helped us whenever we'd created a mess (frequently) but otherwise encouraged our efforts and all the while we quietly chatted. We had the help of our interpreter but actually Muy Sua Bel could do quite well himself. We were completely relaxed and comfortable and this morning gave us a very different understanding of the harsh realities of Cambodia's past as well as the challenges of the present. But mostly, it was again a chance to see up close these people's generous and resilient spirit. I would highly recommend this experience.

Street food tour: recommended!. We did the street food tour after visiting the temples, the old market, the floating village, national museum and so on, and I can say it was one the best experiences we had in siem reap. We tasted local fruits, typical cambodian street food, desserts, insects and even frogs (at least we were supposed to!), in many different places only locals go. Soy is a great guide, so this is higly recommended.

Great activities in Siem Reap.. We participated in a bag making class and martial arts class with our young son. Both were well organized and worth the money. I do wonder how much money the locals running the activities actually receive. We had an English speaking translator for both classes.

A lot of fun, highly recommended.. My wife, 9 year old son and I experienced the Fear Factor experience comprised of cooking and eating grasshoppers, silkworms and tarantulas. Our host was excellent and is a vendor in the market, and our facilitator was also friendly and helped us to understand the process, and also context. The host's young son was also there which was a bonus as it was great having him interact with our son encouraging him to sample the food as he was a bit reluctant. This experience involved deep-frying in hot oil so may not be appropriate for very young children. This is a wonderful social enterprise that supports families and communities directly. One tip - given that this fare is usually served with beer, I suggest you bring a couple of cold brews with you. Highly recommended and will challenge you on what is considered food, and why- at least it did for me.

Street food tour. We did the local street food tour in Siem Reap. It was absolutely fantastic! We were with just the two of us. Our guide Soy Kosal came to pick us up at the hotel with a tuktuk. We drove straight to one of the markets, where only local people come. We were amazed by what we saw and tasted. This is the real cambodia, no tourists here! We could say what we wanted to try. We tasted several fruits, desserts, insects and so on. Also had a stuffed frog. It was really tasty and the guide was very friendly and spoke good English. He was happy to answer al our questions about the food and Cambodian life in general. I can highly recommend this tour to anyone who wants to taste something different and be a part of real Cambodian lifestyle.

Incredible and unique experience. Our family had an a great time with the fear factor challenge. The whole experience was fascinating. Our host, translator, and the local program manger were fantastic. If you are a participant in life and not just a spectator, you'll enjoy this adventure.

Excellent activity. We have been to backstreet academy twice during our stay in Siem Reap. We first went to the stone carving class, which was great. The teacher was very good and spoke good English. We were able to chat to him about Cambodia while we made our carving and we were pleased with the tea light holders we made. We went back for another class in Palm wood carving which was also excellent. This time we had an interpreter, provided by the academy. The teachers were both patient, kind and helpful. We were pleased with all of the things we made. This is a great way to support local people and to learn more about Cambodian skills and life. One tip: wear old clothes as the work can be dusty. We would really recommend this activity.

Cement bags and Iron pencil sketching. Our family of four (2 adults and 2 kids of 3 and 4 years old) decided to take a break from the temples. We booked two courses: the cement bags making for the girls and the iron pencil sketching for the boys. We had a wonderful time. The kids, although small, had such a blast because the staff was so attentive and willing to involve them in the different classes. We keep fantastic memories of the morning spent with the Backstreet Academy!

Cambodian cooking. We had a great time on this cooking course and made and tasted some delicious traditional Khmer food. Both our host cook and our English speaking guide were lovely and made us feel very welcome. Be prepared that the market tour at the beginning is quite dirty and very Cambodian but once you get back to the guides house it's fine. She had a fan and bottled water which was fantastic in the hot weather! A great afternoon!

Cambodian Cooking Class. This was our second Backstreet Academy experience, and like the other, it was a tremendous experience. We like the whole concept and the well-organzied way it is put together.The highlight of our Cambodian Cooking Class was the translator, Manath (last name Duong). She was fun, intelligent, personable, and very helpful throughout the course. She made the course for us. It was difficult to get to know the host, mostly because of the language barrier. This was more of a Cambodian Cooking Demonstration rather than a Cambodian Cooking Class. She did the shopping while we watched, and Manath told us what she knew of the foods. The host did most of the cooking and we chopped a few vegetables. The market where we shopped was fascinating, out in the counry, full of local women doing their shopping, but filthy. The host is the mother of ten children. Several of them were around while she cooked and we had a great time interacting with them. If you would like an unrefined gritty experience of Cambodian rural markets and eating local food with a Cambodian family, as it really is for many Cambodians, then you should really enjoy this class.

Iron Pencil Class. We did the Iron Pencil Sketching class & it was wonderful! It is absolutely amazing how good Reoum Bunhak is with an iron pencil! We had so much fun learning from him. It is a great way to connect with local people in a meaningful way. Reoum helped each of us with our chosen picture & we were able to come away with really nice & meaningful souvenirs. Iron pencil carving is challenging but Reoum makes it fun. Take a class at Backstreet. You will have a wonderful time!

Awesome coconut carving. I'm so glad we found this place on Tripadvisor!. We were looking for something to do other than temples, and booked the coconut shell carving at about 8 pm last night. We were confimed last night for a 12 pm session today. This is a little pricey, but well worth the money. My family spent about 2 hours cutting out little shapes (stars, bunnies, fish, etc) from coconut shells. as a previous reviewer said, the coconut is much harder to cut than I thougt it would be. My eight year old was fine, but my six year old struggled. Both the artist and interpreter were very patient and kind to her especially when she cut off her bunny head by accident and knicked her finger with the little saw that we were using :( After we cut out the shapes, the artist turned them into beautiful keys chains. My girls helped polish them after he sanded them and added his finishing accent touches. It was really fun to spend time making something together as a family. The place where we did the carving has lots of other classes going on and you can buy some really nice gifts. It's quiet and tranquil, quite a nice change from the chaos of the temples that we explored the day before. Assuming that the money really does go to a good cause, and I have no reason to suspect otherwise, it was definietly money and time well spent.

Copper bangle making was awesome. Myself and the wife did the copper bangle making,it was so much fun.Friendly and helpful staffFinal product was amazing if I do say so myself :)Definitely worth doing.The place is a little hard to find but it is about 200m on the right walking away from the hospital on the road behind Sofitel Hotel.

Great human experience and so much fun !. We did the flute making and the cambodian boxing in the same day and it was perfect ! The cambodian boxing was taught by two young boxers, as funny as skilled in their art, so we had a really good time. The flute making was in the BackStreet Academy HQ, in a sunny courtyard and we learned a lot through our instructor, at the end we left with our flutes and the one he made and gave us as a gift ! Our facilitator and the BackStreet Academy manager also took a lot of time to talk with us between the two classes, it was great to spend quality time with them while drinking the good coconuts they offered us. This is a real human experience, an ecotouristic choice and a funny moment you can't miss.

Wish we found this sooner!. After checking out some attractions in Siem Reap we came across Backstreet Academy and quickly started reading through the potential classes. Torn between at least 3 we opted for the wood carving class. At times we have sporadic WiFi in our hotel room, so after putting a booking in and paying the booking fee we got a little worried we didn't hear back, however with the WiFi being sporadic and us heading out to dinner we shouldn't have worried as an email was waiting with instructions. When we arrived we met our translator who was a lovely lady, and our instructor Ann. He was very skilled, and although he was a quiet man, he didn't hesitate to help hold the tools right for us as we banged away with the mallet, he had a lot of trust in us! At times I wish I could if just watched Ann work on a more elaborate piece, as when he took over to assist or show us what to do for part of the carving, I was mesmerised by his skill. After this taster I am really keen to try some other classes and even more so to develop my skill in Wood Carving. We were also treated with a coconut milk drink during our visit, that was a fantastic gesture, and it was tasty!Thank you to Backstreet Academy for providing these classes, and thankyou to Ann for sharing your skill with us!

Do it! Wonderful experience. Great memories.. I did the Dessert Making class (http://www.backstreetacademy.com/course/details/339) and it was one of my favorite experiences in Cambodia. When people think of Siem Reap they think (much like I did) Angkor Wat, and that's it. I had a day spare though and wanted to delve deeper into the social culture. Sometimes the easiest way to do that is through food, so I decided to search online for a cooking class. My translator was so friendly, a great conversationalist, she answered all my questions. My host was very welcoming, organised and so talented - I have no cooking talent, so the fact she managed to get me to make something that tasted delicious was a miracle - well done!I was so happy I got to spend time with people who were local to the area, they were so warm and fun to be around and left me with great memories. I highly recommend this course and the Siem Reap Backstreet Academy.

Very fun and a great break from the temples. I actually read the reviews here and decided to join a class with Backstreet Academy and now I really recommend people doing it if they would like a break from the temples. I joined the copper bracelet class and it was so much fun hammering patterns into the copper plate. The teachers there are very patient and they have given good instructions to a beginner like me. It's so rewarding to get my final product!

Fantastic Experience!. I had an Apsara Dance lesson. The staff and dance teacher were very friendly and I really enjoyed the lesson.I will coming back for that and want to try interesting culture classes. Thanks!!!Thank you!!
Great idea, allows local people to teach and inspire. We have done two backstreet academies and loved them both. A proper local taste of arts and crafts and the money goes to the person teaching you.

Great Apsara dance class. I took an Apsara dance class with a friend. We had a local coordinator who spoke English and helped us with the communication with the instructor. Booking was very easy - made through the website, and received a confirmation a few hours later. Very good price too.

Learn from true craftspeople while in Siem Reap - a must do!. Take a break from monuments to spend creative time with local craftspeople! We took the soapstone carving and iron pencil sketching classes and wish we had more days to spend exploring their other options. What a great way to spend time with locals! This organization is about creating access to markets for local artisans and communities that might not otherwise have an outlet for their creative endeavors or the ability to make a living with them. A big part of their mission is re-invigorating economically disadvantaged communities and preserving and maintaining local arts. The artists don't always speak a lot of English, so the organization assigns facilitators to act as welcoming hosts for the students and as translators. While working, we swapped vocabulary words with the instructor, shared food and laughter (lots of laughter!), and felt like we came away with new friends. We also did a LOT of our shopping in their marketplace area, which felt great since we knew the funds were going to support the communities that make the crafts rather than a lot of middlemen. There was zero pressure to buy anything, we simply wanted to after taking the classes. A great experience and a fantastic way to spend a day!

Unique Iron Pencil Sketching. We had a fantastic iron pencil sketching with our Cambodian master Bun Hak, founder of a unique new type of art--Iron Pencil Sketching. Using hot iron to "scar" the wood, Bun Hak is able to create some really amazing sketches and under his tutelage I was able to complete a grand sketch of Angkor Wat complete with elephants and giant Buddhist carvings. I left Cambodia with a unique souvenir that I don't think people would ever believe was sketched by me (and the master). I would definitely try Backstreet Academy courses the next time I head to any places where they are available!

Excellent experience- a must do for Siem Reap. Copper Bracelet - completed the copper bracelet class today. Booked it all via emails, all very easy with fast replies. The whole class was very well set up, teachers were amazing, and loved my bracelet at the end! I really would recommend anyone coming to Siem Reap to do this class! Cement Bag- my boyfriend did this class while I did my bracelet. He said the teachers were really great and helped a sewing beginner make an iPad case. He was really pleased with his bag! The whole team at Backstreet Academy were all so lovely and I urge people to try one of the classes!!

Nice Bugs cooking class. Backstreet Academy tries to help local artisans making up their wages teaching tourists what they best do. I applied for the Fear Factor Challenge and it was really fun! There was a nice girl being the translator for the day. The course was held in the garden of the "teacher", that actually sells cooked bugs for a living at the Siem Reap market. I had the chance to cook (and eat) a lot of delicious crickets, silk worms, and tarantulas (very tasty!). I had a lot of fun and in the end, most of what i paid went directly to the teacher (I saw the facilitator splitting the money, and just a couple of dollars or so was taken by the Academy).

(DYI) Brilliant Brass Bracelets!. Great, great idea: you go to an atelier where they have hand-crafted jewelry and they show you how to make it yourself! Granted, our versions were all of the simplified variety, but it was still an amazing experience and one that had us hammering away whilst humming "whistle while you work". Okay, maybe not the last bit, but it was incredible all the same.The skinny: you have to allot about 3 hours for the whole process, so if you're on a tight schedule, this workshop is not for you. In other words, if you're in Siem Reap for just one day, you should skip this. However, if you're in town for 3-4 days, this is an excellent way to mix things up and take a break from the temple tours. The best part: the local craftsmen show you exactly how to pound out your designs, so even if you're doing only the decorative work and they're doing the heavy lifting with the butane flame, etc., your handiwork is what people see as the end-product. The bad:- you must be a little "crafty", i.e. not afraid to pound out your design with a hammer- it's a little slow-going at first- you can only choose the simpler designs as templates (because of time constraints)The good:- definitely a one-of-a-kind experience- really nice to have to final product in hand (that you made!)- totally cool to watch the whole process unfold in front of youSo if you're in Siem Reap and you're a bit templed-out, definitely carve out an afternoon and go for one of Backstreet Academy's workshops. Totally worth it!

Brilliant Bug Cooking Class - yum!. Two of us had a 'fear factor' bug cooking class this morning and we loved the experience! Our teacher, Rathana, was an expert, and our facilitator/translator, Srey Leak, was lovely and spoke great English. We had a really good time with them and they even got us to eat a whole tarantula each! It was really hands on too. Highly recommended :)

Arts n craft fun for the family!. This is a social enterprise that seeks to direct tourist $ directly & more efficiently into the local economy. It brings together local craftsmen and tourists for fun-filled arts n craft classes!Activities suit all ages. My 5 & 8 yr olds had flute making and coconut carving classes while we had iron pencil classes.We took 3hrs to complete - it can be tough going but we had a lot of fun. Best of all we talked to the locals and saw the direct beneficiaries of our tourist $. A wonderful 3hrs spent.This place is new so tuk tuk drivers may not know how to get there. Call ahead to setup appointment with instructors.
Iron pencil drawing.. Great fun, and we had a wonderful souvenir to take home at the end of the class! The people were kind, helpful and spoke good English.

So much talent. Did the iron drawing workshop and learnt an art that only one man does, it is his own creation. It was amazing to see his skills where he took a hot iron rod out of the fire and burnt a A4 size Palm tree board to create gorgeous pictures of the Angkor temples and any picture you wish. He created his Art over 13 years and we barely managed an artist straight line in 4 hours when we tried but he turned our attempts into masterpieces. A wonder organization that supports local artists, gives you an expectional experience, a uni student English practice and a souvenir with meaning! Great activites and there is lots of choices for the kids too.

Flute making class - enjoyable . We did the flute making class and it was very enjoyable. The interpreter was charming and enjoyable to chat to with excellent English and the teacher spoke some English too and was very patient. He had a very high level of skill and although my husband did most of the work to make the flute which he was very happy with, the teacher kindly added some nice finishing touches. They were also very considerate setting up a fan for us and bringing us fresh coconut and water to keep us hydrated. Great experience.

Great Fun!. Palm wood carving was the only class available on short notice, and though the chisel was scary and the electric sander heavy, Chum Kiel was a patient teacher and our jointly crafted project (a plate, fork and spoon) came out wonderfully. Make sure to tell your tuktuk driver to wait for you. The artisan workshop is a bit off the beaten track for tuktuks, but fortunately someone offered to take me back to the hotel on her motorbike. A great way to meet the locals.

Nice but not as expected. If you have some spare time you will enjoy it, but their are not much artists and the things are more expensive than the night market. Its worth going if you want to learn how to make some cambodian craft but it will take you at least two hrs.

Having fun with new experience. Today morning my boyfriend and me was having "flute making class". We did it step by step as what instructor told us.The instructor was very patient. I never had made it before. Everyone are friendly and they knew how to flute in very properly. I can't understand what song they were fluting. I just fluted it to make a noise not a song. That was very funny time for us and I enjoyed this class so much. we can share the experience with the local people, the way they live and learn about Cambodian culture more. Don't forget try it!

Delightful Experience!. I had a wonderful experience as a participant in the Backstreet Academy! I took the "Iron Pencil" class and was amazed at the talent of the instructor. He was not only a true artist, but was incredibly patient as he supported me through the process. The philosophy of this NGO is fabulous as it not only offers a fair wage to the artists but also provides a valuable learning opportunity for the participants. I highly recommend this wonderful opportunity!

Soap stone carving having fun. Good experience. Instructors English was limited, as was the translators. We carved a 2D elephant out of soapstone. When I say "we" the instructor did over half of it, but I guess the idea was to make sure we had something to show at the end. My 9 year old son really enjoyed the carving, not so much the watching and got a little bored by the end of it. Would have been good to have a choice on what to carve and to have seen a finished version before we started as we were a little in the dark as to what it was supposed to look like. But overall a good time was had and it was a different way to spend the morning.

Fun Time!. Even though I have never taken a dance class in my life, I thought it would be fun to try the Apsara class to learn more about this exquisitely beautiful, traditional form of movement. Although it was quite tricky to pick up the moves, I had fun trying and laughing at myself. I think I gave the girls a good laugh, too! My guide and the dance instructor were both very friendly, fun and patient. More than anything, I enjoyed chatting with them and learning more about their lives.I also wanted to take the cooking class, however it was unfortunately booked. This is a great program with a wide variety of interesting opportunities to learn about Cambodian culture. Definitely worth checking out.

Potery class with NO instructions, disapointing.. My boyfriend and I decided to do the pottery class. We decided to go with backstreet academy instead of khmer ceramics fine arts center since backstreet appeared to be more of an experience with the locals. Having read the good reviews we had high expectations. However, we were pretty disapointed. When we got there they made us sit at the pottery station and basicly told us to push on the thing with our feet. The lady was then making the pottery with her hands. It went on like this with no explanation for a while and we had to ask if we could try ourselves. (The ladies where really good and it was impressive to see their work, but when it was our turn the translator didnt provide any explanations on how to do it and it always ended up being the ladies finishing the project). The website says the course is supposed to last 2-3 hours but after an hour and a half they said that it would be better if we finished now because "the road gets silent" ( the place where you do the pottery is 300m from the airport road so it is not a silent road at 6pm).I am aware that pottery isnt easy, and not something you can be succesful at after a 2 hour class, however having basic instructions and tricks would have made the experience totaly different.p.s. if they tell you to meet at the ankhor mundial restaurant, this restaurant has moved a few months ago so be sure to go at the one located on the airport street. I wouldnt recommend doing the pottery class, but backstreet academy seems to have other options so maybe try another class!
A Must do. Did the iron pencil scetching,had a fantastic time. Highly recommend, it is great fun and you get a unique souviener

Great Way to Meet the Locals. My husband and I did three Backstreet Academy activities this week. We did the copper/silver bracelet class, the copper wire bracelet class and the cement bag class. All were excellent, I learned news skills, gained appreciation for what these craftsmen do and interacted with some lovely locals. I was most impressed by Bel, our teacher at the copper wire jewelry class and founder of the NGO KILT. Despite a hard upbringing and loss of a leg from a land mind, Bel has a can do attitude and today, he not only provides for his families, but helps others with disabilities that might otherwise be neglected. Backstreet Academy opens your mind and your heart.

Great experience with lovely people. My husband and I booked a jewellery making course over the Internet from Australia. Samon from Backstreet Academy was easy to communicate with and extremely helpful. The course was fun and it was great chatting with some local people while we made our creations. Highly recommended as something different to do when you get sick of the temples and the money goes to charity

Amazing!. An amazing experience - a real highlight of my two weeks in Cambodia. We did the rubber tire making course that was an eye opener and i got to experience a different side of cambodia. We also so enjoyed our experience and what the Backstreet Academy is trying to do we also took the copper bracelet course (which is much harder than it looks!)

Great experience. I've learned via Backstreet academy to do wood carving, and my friend did apsara dance.We had both a really nice time, learning those cambodgian traditions, with the help of very nice persons to translate us.I definitely recommend Backstreet academy, it's one of the best memories of our stay in Siem Reap!

Backstreet cooking class. We had a great time on Thursday 20th November doing the cooking class in Siem Reap. Great company, delicious food and we learnt recipes that we could definitely use back home in Australia.

Made an ipad case out of used cement bags!. I'm a tree hugger so you could imagine how I was in love with the idea of making an ipad case out of used cement bags! We were able to book a class via e-mail. We didn't have to make any deposit but the class cost us $15 per head. It's fun and for a great cause too because Backstreet Academy is a social enterprise. The course took us two hours to finish with the help of three instructors for three students. We were asked to describe what kind of bag we wanted to make. From creating the measurements, cutting the bags, lining, foam, to using sewing machines to put it all together, we were guided every step of the way. Even if I had absolutely no skill in cutting and sewing whatsoever, the instructors will make sure that the product you come up with will still come out beautiful and worthy to bring home as a souvenir.

Excellent company. We have been to three classes and loved each one of them. The copper bracelet was so exciting to learn and we ended up with a beautiful memento. The iron pencil craft or hot poker work was so interesting and we all have a wonderful picture for our walls. We also enjoyed water colours and painted two typical Cambodian scenes. The company is very efficient and professional and is such a bonus for Siem Reap. The tutors are lovely and there is a translator provided. I am going back!

Incredible. My sister wanted to do this and initially I was hesitant because I didn't know if I wanted to take time away from seeing more of the Angkor temples to do arts and crafts which I wasn't really into as much. But then I went to the website and realized they have a ton of different types of activities, from Kmer martial arts to horseback riding you can do through Backstreet academy. We had a hard time deciding what to do. We took the stone carving course with Mr. Poy Khet and I am so glad we did! Most of the temples in the Angkor complex are carved out of sandstone, which is exactly what we used for carving. You feel a great connection to the people who built the temple complexes as you use a hammer and chisel to create something out of it. You also gain a huge appreciation for how difficult it must have been to create the vast temple complexes. We created stone flowers that could hold candles. It was a much better souvenir to bring home than anything from the touristy markets in the area. Mr. Poy Khet is a great teacher. He is very experienced and patient and will help you in any way he can.

Pencil Sketching Class. My wife attended the pencil sketching class on November 9, 2014. We found out about program on Tripadvisor as the academy is one of the top rated things to do in Siem Reap. After browsing all of the available activities, my wife decided to try out the afternoon pencil sketching class.
