We were able to make a booking on November 9 at 5PM on November 8 because of the fast reply from the academy.  On the day, the instructor and facilitator arrived 15 minutes before the course time at the Angkor Handicraft Association. My wife was offered to pick a picture she wants to sketch from a list of photos, and she selected the 4-face temple in Angkor Thom. Both the instructor and facilitator were very friendly and patiently taught my wife how to sketch.  After about 2 hours, my wife was able to finish her very first pencil sketching in Siem Reap. She found the course to be extremely fun and rewarding. The instructor also gave us his copy for free - what an amazing gift! It was also relaxing to shop at the Angkor Handicraft association which is entirely dedicated to the local talented artists in Siem Reap.
Only ok. Didn't enjoy the class as much as I thought I would.... Translation was hard to understand and didn't do very much painting at all- instructor painted most of the picture

make your best souvenir. I did my sandstone course with Mr. Poy. He constructed me for the 3hrs with patient and his 16years experience. At the same time, he shared his knowledge about carving,materials and even his carving life. Finally he carved my name on the Khmer alphabet under my art work. That is the best souvenirs I got in SR.while I was waiting for the teacher, they have someone explained to me about the flower that we are going to carve and why it got chosen, they were able to answer all my questions about sandstone carving. I am now more understand and appreciate the hard work behind stone carving. This experience keeps reminding me those carving I have seen in Angkor temples.

Brilliant fun at Angkor Handicraft Association. We had an excellent time at the Angkor Handicraft Association (back street academy) in Siem Reap, doing a bit of coconut carving. The people were very friendly and even managed to teach a useless bunch like us. Lots of other activities going on and a great shop, with the proceeds going back into the local community, most of which I would have taken home baggage allowance permitting.

fun and creative, learn from local khmer artist. I had a couple of hours to spare and wanted to try something different away from hoardes of tourists, and Backstreet Academy was all that! This place is fantastic and I highly recommend if you are looking for something a little different and want to spend time chatting with locals while you are at it.From my initial phone call, they were incredibly friendly and helpful, and when I couldn't find them, they sent a staff member on moto to come and meet me! I took the pencil sketching session as this was available at short notice on the day that I called, and it was a lot of fun, and a nice relaxed activity after a lot of time out and about in the heat. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit, my teacher was superb, and the translator was great fun and very encouraging. And I had a lovely pencil sketch to take away as a momento. They have a great set-up, I never felt rushed or stuck on a timetable, and it really seemed that they love sharing what they do with others. Next time I am back in Siem Reap, I will be back to try another of their classes! Really impressed with my experience at Backstreet Academy!

Done with Temples? Meet lovely people & create a Cambodian souvenir. I needed a day off to recover between hot, long days at the temples so I looked on Tripadvisor & found Backstreet Academy! The reviews were fantastic, so I decided to try it. The Khmer snack class I initially wanted to take wasn't available but they quickly emailed me back to tell me they had a cement bag laptop sleeve class. It was $15 and was supposed to take 3 hours, but since I was the only person in class I got it finished in 1.5 hours, with the help of the fantastic teacher & translator they provided! The ladies were a joy to spend time with and I am now looking forward to taking other BA classes in Phnom Pehn or Hanoi. Their location is a bit off the beaten trail but absolutely worth finding! Their location also has a large gallery of crafts for sale at reasonable prices, so buy your souvenirs here! Thank you for a memorable afternoon, Backstreet Academy!

Fun activity and definitely something new!. These mini-experiences are a great idea and well executed by Backstreet academy. I live in Siem Reap and have now done a couple and they are a great time. The bracelet making was an awesome and fun opportunity to meet a local silversmith and I ended up with a really cute piece of jewellery. I did it with a group of friends and we had a good laugh about how untalented we were. With the instructors help though, the finished product always kinda works out. I've also done the oil painting, which again was a hoot. Of course you aren't going to learn how to be a professional oil painter in an afternoon at a cost of $12 -- what you will get is a tonne of laughs, the opportunity to chat with local artists and a beautiful souvenir that you can brag about back home. They are really good value for money experiences and offer a controlled setting to talk to Khmer artists about anything you want to.

Coconut carving: Different and memorable experience. Our family of five took the coconut carving workshop, and had a great time! Something very different in addition to the temples, floating villages and markets. This experience was hands-on, with two local artisans and our translator, who joined in as well. Our youngest at six years was a bit young to use the tools, so she helped out with various jobs rather than making her own carving, and she felt just as accomplished as the rest of us once we had finished our three key rings each in various designs. (I recommend a minimum age of around 8 to do the carving). It turns out that coconut carving is quite a skill! This will be a memory that will last a long time.

Something speical at Siem Reap. Four of us joined the 2 hours horse riding. We all have no experience for this. An experience leader went with us at front and he took us to the village and temple nearby and introduced in details. This is a very speical experience to allow us to know more about local Siem Reap.There are also 2 guys help leading our horse at the begining to make sure we all riding ok. They are all very friendly and helpful. We enjoyed it very much. I wish I could enrolled some other activities next time.

Absolutely wonderful experience. I took a class in sewing cement bags and had a wonderful time. The teacher was pleasant, patient and lots of fun. Translator and facilitator joined in and I had an unforgettable experience. I took the class the day before I left Siem Reap or I would have enrolled in some others as I enjoyed this one so much. An absolute must do. (review submitted on behalf of my travelling companion Christine Bowman)

Great morning painting. The oil painting class was extraordinary. We had a delightful tutor, Mr Mallivan, who showed us a bunch of interesting and effective painting techniques. Our products were great too - thanks in most part to the skills of Mr Mallivan. Mr Samon was an absolute delight who escorted us personally to the site of the class. Sitting under the trees painting is one of those things that just makes you feel good! Great company, great class, great morning! Thanks to all at Backstreet Academy in Siem Reap.

Awesome. I actually took several different classes, stone carving, cement bags, and copper bracelet. The artisan were amazing and so helpful as I bungled my way through. There is a little reassure to buy something from their shops but after try to make something for myself I was even more impressed by the skills of the teacher.

Local craft experience Luang Prabang, Laos. Going on an outing with Backstreet academy to visit a local crafts person in Luang Prabang, Laos provided me with an opportunity to experience something that normally I would have definitely missed.I’d seen the multitude of local crafts displayed at the famous night market of Luang Prabang, but my outing with Backstreet Academy took my beyond that, to the world of the people who sell their crafts at the night market, day in day out, in order to make a living.I was collected at about nine o’clock in the morning by a tuktuk that carried also my Backstreet Academy guide, or as they are called, ‘facilitator’ who explained to me our plan for the morning as well as the way Backstreet Academy works. In all the aspects of a trip we were on, BA’s objective is to let the local people involved in their activities benefit from it financially. This applies to the crafts person hosting the visitor, the facilitator, who’s a young Lao student trying to improve language and interaction skills with foreigners as well as making some cash, as well as the tuktuk driver who’s ensured to, working with Backstreet Academy, have a steady amount of work. I’d learned this before on the BA website and it was the main reason that I joined Backstreet Academy on one of their outings. After a friendly chat with my facilitator we arrived at the place of Ms Ga Thor, a kind young lady who was going to be our host for the next few hours in which she would show me how the cute and warm house-slippers that I’d seen displayed everywhere at the night market, are made. During the process it was fascinating to see how Ms Ga Thor lives and learn a little about her life. At 30 years of age she is the mother of 4, her oldest being 15. She lives in a 5 by 8 metre one-room house in which 3 corners are occupied by beds that, at night, accommodate the 8 people living in the house. In the fourth corner is the kitchen.In the middle of this Ms Ga Thor has her hand-powered sewing machine which is essential in the production of the house-slippers. While neighbours and relatives gathered around to watch us, Ms Ga Thor showed me how to make house-slippers, demonstrating that it was not so easy, by letting me having a go at it. I was happy that in the end she rescued me from my poor attempts to work the sewing machine to produce 2 lovely looking house-slippers which she then presented to me. It had been a worthwhile undertaking from the moment I had stepped into Ms Ga Thor’s home but after receiving the house-slippers I was honoured with another gift when Ms Ga Thor handed me, and put a pretty hand-made bracelet on my wrist. From my visit to Ms Ga Thor it was clear that she and her family do depend greatly on each little bit of income that they can gather, and the idea that some of the money I paid for this outing (which I thought was little) goes to Ms Ga Thor (and, not to forget, to the tuktuk driver as well as the facilitator), made the whole experience for me a very pleasant one.‘Good show’ Backstreet Academy.

Oil painting in Siem Reap. I did the oil painting class while visiting Siem Reap and I must say that it was one of the most unique experiences I've had on my travels! I'm not an artistic person but with the help of the teacher and translator, I was able to produce a small oil painting of my own in about 2 hours! The teacher and translator were incredibly warm and friendly which made the experience so enjoyable, and I have a nice momento of my trip to take home! Highly recommended!

Such a wonderful cultural immersion. I took the stone carving and palm wood carving class in Backstreet Academy and it was so fun and memorable! Both my teachers were extremely skilled craftsmen and great teachers and I learned a lot from them. It was really interesting to see and be able to make my own version Cambodian art. It made me appreciate those local art pieces so much more, knowing how much work is put into each and every one. It was such a nice way to immerse myself with the locals and in local art too-- truly one of the things I'll never forget about my Cambodia adventure. Thanks to the great staff behind Backstreet Academy (operations manager, teachers) for being efficient and helpful from the first time I enrolled in the class to my actual participation! You guys rock! :)

Iron Pencil Sketching. One of my favourite experiences from Cambodia so far! Wonderful people, an amazing talent and an incredibly enjoyable morning. Bun Hak showed us his craft of Hot Iron Pencil Sketching where a hot iron is used to burn a picture onto Palm leaves. Bun Hak made it look incredibly easy, his workmanship is incredible, a true artisan! He helped us to create some magnificent work, without his help it would have been tricky but it was a nice technique to try, my wife has a steadier hand than I so took to it very well which surprised Bun Hak given how tricky his craft is!Our translator Srey Net was on hand, who was incredibly helpful and attentive, providing us with fresh coconut water in the hot sun.Samon and Navy run an excellent business, a brilliant idea that should be expanded to all countries. Trying your hand at local artistic techniques is something everyone should try while travelling especially in Siem Reap. It's unique and a great way to experience Cambodian craft.The team at Backstreet Academy were all lovely and Bun Hak had even created an iron pencil sketch just for us as we were on our honeymoon.All in all, easily one of my favourite experiences from Cambodia, even if I wasn't a natural!

"Fear factor" aka cooking and eating bugs . My gf and I did the fear factor course today. It was a fun experience! After meeting the translator they took us to Mr. Ratana's backyard (which can get hot so bring water and suncream!) where we met our 'guide'. The house was also full of children playing around and keen to watch which was fun. The whole thing was very authentic, we really were hanging out with the locals.We cooked crickets, worms and the the big prize, some tarantulas. I actually really enjoyed the crickets! My gf liked the worms, and the tarantula was..an experience! Overall couldn't recommend this more, was a welcome break from the tourist circuit that is siem reap

Too much temples and sightseeing? Come here.. My sister and I spent a few days in Siem Reap doing all the touristy stuff. We went to Angkor and saw those temples, we went to the markets, we even went hours out of the city to see other temples and ruins. So for our last day, with our bus leaving in the evening, we quickly searched for something different to do for a few hours during the day. My sister found Backstreet Academy on Tripadvisor. We quickly read over the reviews and saw that everyone seemed to really like it. So we sent an email the night before and didn't think that we would get a response in time for their 9am class the next day. When we got up the next morning (without any plans of what to do) we received an email from them telling us that they could take us for the cement bag class. Our tuk-tuk driver had a hard time finding the place, he ended up having to call them and they directed him there. They stood outside and greeted us. My sister and I each had a lady help us do our own project (i made a bag and she made a laptop/ipad case). After talking we found out that the ladies were sisters too. There was also another girl whom was like an interpreter. She was really helpful in explaining and answering our questions. They were all so nice and friendly. They provided us with water bottles and let us do everything on our own. The class was about 3hrs and once we were done everyone clapped and you just feel so accomplished. They had a tuk-tuk driver ready to bring us back and they even gave us key chains. After talking to the program manager here I realized that they have these classes in other cities as well. If i were to visit them I'd definitely go to a class. But for now, I definitely recommend these people here at Backstreet Academy in Siem Reap. They're just so genuine and friendly!

Horse Riding and Cement Bags. I came across the Tripadvisor reviews for Backstreet Academy so decided to have a relaxing day with the horse riding and cement bag courses. Both places were extremely accommodating, especially in light of my sprained ankle.Both of these were great fun and I really enjoyed the experience that both offered.I had Chey as my horse riding guide - he had great English and was giving a commentary of the area whilst walking past rice paddies, lotus flower ponds and local homes. The horses were well looked after and the owner is enabling these guys (and girls!) skills and experience they would not have.I love my laptop bag from the cement bag course - although I would attribute it more to my instructor's guidance, not my (lack of) inner seamstress. It was a relaxing way to pass the afternoon and get to know the ladies (and guy!). If I was staying longer, I would have booked in more courses :)

Authentic and a bit different. We found the Backstreet Academy on Trip Advisor and booked last minute to take the class where you can make bags from recycled cement sacks.After experiencing so many tourist traps on our travels it was really nice to spend a quiet afternoon with the local girls. They were so lovely and very patient with the complicated and fiddly process of bag making.At the end we came away with a unique souvenir rather than the generic stuff you find in the markets. I highly recommend to anyone looking to do something a bit different. I would try one of the other classes if I went back to Siem Reap (or any of the other places they have the Backstreet Academy).

"Fear Factor Challenge". We booked the "Fear Factor Challenge" and where picked up in time and where driven to Mr. Ratanas backyard for todays cooking class. It was just us two. We got a very warm welcoming by the crew and got introduced to the food. 3 types of creepy crawlers ready to be prepared. We where really suprised by the good taste of all these insects and to learn about the background story of eating them.

Iron Pencil Sketching - we LOVED it!. We had a really special afternoon working with our wonderful instructor Bunhak and facilitator. Bunhak let us chose our favorite designs then showed us how to create beautiful works of art on palm canvases using hot iron 'pencils' to burn away areas to give a really unusual finsh. He was very patient and kind and under his guidance we very quickly managed to get a hang of the technique. Bunhak was there to help whenever we got a bit stuck and at the end he gave our pictures a wonderful finishing touch. For a really unique experience we highly recommend iron pencil sketching - get to meet and watch the amazing skills of Bunhak, choice from a range of images and create a personal and memorable souvenir. Thanks Backstreet!

Cement bags. We spend the afternoon making our own cement bags and enjoyed every minute of the workshop. It was a great experience with patient wonderful staff with the added bonus of finishing the afternoon with our indivdual cement bags to take home. Would recommend Backstreet Academy as a low cost way of experiencing Camodian handicrafts and learning a hands on skill. Judy & Debra

Leather Carving. My daughter chose to do the Leather Carving course and I went along a bit reluctantly, but we both enjoyed it and are very pleased with want we made. Its a great way to meet the local people, and really makes you appreciated all the hard work that goes into the craft that can be bought for very little in the markets. Our hosts/instructors were much younger that I had expected (early 20s), yet were very attentive and patient. It takes longer than the advertised time to complete your work so it will probably be finished off by the instructor (they a happy to do this for you). The pick up point for the leather carving is the Entrance of Cambodian Cultural Village yet it is best to stop across the road. That is where the course takes place in the Batiment Khmer d' Angkor Thom. The criticism I have of the course is that Backstreet Academy have contracted with the school to have the visitor make a overly ambitious puppet. It is very time consuming and difficult to display once you get it home. A smaller carving without the sticks would be more practical.

Create a gorgeous souvenir smelling palm leaves yourself in a friendly and relaxing atmosphere :). I spent 4 hours at the Backstreet Academy doing the "iron-pencil" sketching of Angkor Wat temple today. This was an amazing experience since I am into handicrafts and a handicraft class taught by a local person is especially interesting. The staff is super friendly: they would accompany you, chat with you and bring you coconut juice ;)Your working table is outdoors but has a roof. First, you will draw a sketch of your future picture (you can use stencil plates with a variety of designs: Bayon, Angkor Wat, Apsara dancers, jungle trees etc). Then you will use long metal sticks to burn the contours, shadows, patterns on your palm leaf. If later on you want to hang your picture on the wall, the artist, Mr.Bun-Hak will make it for you.Consider going to Backstreet Academy- it's really worth visiting, and I hope to visit it again! Many thanks and warm wishes to the Backstreet Academy staff&artists :)
Ceramics painting class!. Backstreet Academy is great! I was recommend by my friend to do the mug painting course. It was so much fun. I made my own drawing on the mugs.
Great experience!!!. I'm a local people, I was finding the place to do the mug painting for my parents. I found a course in Backstreet Academy from my friend! It was so much fun

Loved it!!. I took the Cement Bag class. It was a lot of fun! A lot of work goes into the bags, more than you might think. I loved the bag I made. I picked out the bag and pattern I wanted and cut and did most of the sewing myself with the help of the seamstress. This was a great way to experience the local culture and take a break from the temples.

Amazing cocktail class!. I did the Cambodian Cocktail making class which was brilliant! Our 'teacher' introduced us to all the herbs and spices we would be using first (no 'ordinary' cocktails here!) then we started making. At only $15 I thought it was very good value. The bar itself (Asana) is gorgeous, with floating beds, fairy lights and chilled music. Thank you for a lovely class!

An absolute blast!. I did the "Fear Factor" class with Samon in Siem Reap, and boy was it an experience. I met with Samon and the bug chef, Rapana, outside of Rapana's home not far from the center of town. All the ingredients were ready to go: crickets, grasshoppers, tarantulas, water snake, along with plenty of seasonings. They walked me through preparing each type of bug before frying them up in cooking oil. The crickets were definitely my favorite! Samon was happy to take pictures and a video of me cooking the bugs and trying them (so glad I have a video of me eating a tarantula to show off to my friends). Both guys were seriously super nice, and were excited to share a bit of their culture with me. If you are feeling a bit adventurous, and want an amazing story, then I highly recommend taking the Fear Factor class in Siem Reap.

Amazing time!!. Me and wife had an entire evening free in Siem Reap. We did the temples, the shopping, the eating and we pretty much ran out of things to do. We happen to come across Backstreet Academy's courses and decided to partake in the Khmer cocktail class to pass by the evening, not knowing what to expect. The experience we had completely took us by surprise! A very well organized course got started at a beautiful setting at what they supposedly call the only wooden house in town. One by one, the bartender got us to sample all the spices we would be using before we got onto the drinks. That was quite useful as some of the spices were completely new to us and this also acquainted us with the smell and taste. We made four drinks, three we had a hands on training while the fourth was pretty much free and easy. I really liked that arrangement where the structure was well balanced. The cocktails themselves were delicious, every one of them. Except I would have personally put in an extra shot or two in mine. But that being said, all of them impressed me thoroughly. Later I found that Backstreet Academy also has many other courses around town and checking them out is definitely worth your time. Backstreet Academy should be on every visitor's itinerary!

Very interesting and fun classes. We did two classes with Backstreet Academy - Khmer Cocktails and Cement Bags. Both were fantastic. The cocktail class is in a nice little outdoor bar right in the middle of town. All the ingredients and equipment were set up ready for us when we arrived, and as well as the teacher a representative from Backstreet Academy was there to welcome us. We learned how to make three cocktails, all of which were delicious - especially 'Tamarind Sauce'. The teacher spoke decent English and was really good fun. It's also worth mentioning what outstanding value this was - to order the same three cocktails from the menu would only have cost $1.50 less than taking the class!The following day we did the Cement Bag class in the morning. Actually, we had been supposed to do this the previous day, but our tuk-tuk driver couldn't find the meeting place, and after driving around aimlessly for an hour we had to give up and return to our hotel. I then called Akash at Backstreet Academy, who was extremely apologetic (despite the fact that the problem was in no way their fault) and arranged for us to do the class the next day at no extra cost. He also sent a staff member to meet us at our hotel to prevent the same problem occuring. As the regular instructor was not available, we were taught how to make the bags by two sisters who were doing their first lesson, although I would never have guessed this if we had not been told, as both were great. Throughout the bag-making process, two staff members from Backstreet Academy also helped out, and Akash was also present (and told us lots of interesting information about Backstreet Academy's history and plans). From start to finish the class lasted about 3 hours, by the end of which we each had a great new bag, and were also given a matching wallet and purse, which was a lovely surprise.Overall, we couldn't have had a better experience with Backstreet Academy - everyone we met, staff and teachers, were incredibly friendly and very professional. Our only regret is that we didn't have time to take any more classes, but if in future we visit any of the other cities where they operate then we shall certainly take the chance to learn some new skills! Many thanks to Akash and everyone at Backstreet Academy!

I had such a great time!. I did the leather carving class and even though it was hard work, I was so happy and proud of what I accomplished. I felt like I was taking a long time, but the student teacher and Samon were so patient with me! I highly recommend this experience for anyone hoping to really learn about cultural aspect of Cambodian culture and to give back to a good cause!This backstreet location just opened up a month ago so that's why it only has 4 reviews. I expect it to really take off over the next few months!Please come and participate!

Turn your idea into jewelry you can wear. I had a wonderful morning crafting a copper band bracelet with Backstreet Academy's silversmith. The business was family run and after a bit of ogling in amazement as I watched one of the assistants etch out an intricate classical design for a wall piece, I got to work on my mini piece of art. I brought my own design and step by step, with the guidance of my teacher, I came out with my own handmade bracelet. The feeling of satisfaction put a smile on my face. Overall I had a fantastic time and would highly encourage others to check out and select from Backstreet's offerings for a unique experience.

Rewarding Fear Factor Challenge Experience. The Fear Factor Challenge experience was interesting in an unexpected way.My partner's biggest fear is insects. However, he decided to test his limits by signing up for the Fear Factor Challenge. Seeing him so excited about his experience made me excited too.What was unexpected was that the experience of watching Mr Ratana (insect chef) clean, trim, season and fry his insects was very appetizing. So experienced he looked as he fried his insects, it made the insects feel no different from other regular food. Smells really good with the spices too. My partner did the unexpected and partook of the crickets. And... Enjoyed it. And there after went on a rampage with the tarantula and the grasshopper. In his words, "After you get over the initial shock of looking at the insect and you put it in your mouth, it's actually quite tasty." I diligently took mental notes of all the ingredients going with the insects and helped to do the marination of the insects myself. It was an interesting experience. I would be able to fry crickets now if anyone tasks me too! Bring it on. Haahahaahah...The whole experience was very well organised and felt really special. Transport was arranged for us and we travelled through a maze of Cambodian houses before arriving to Mr Ratana's place. Its completely unlike the typical tourist experience as it felt like Mr Ratana is sharing a part of his daily life with us. So much more genuine and personal.Whilst Mr Ratana was teaching us how to fry the insects, his wife was at the side trimming the wings of grasshoppers one by one. And his super cute son was playing with all the live grasshoppers. Its fun playing with his son. Not at all shy and though we didn't speak the same language, fun is an international language I suppose.The facilitators at Backstreet were really nice too. They got us a big bottle of water on their own accord. Samon from Backstreet shared a funny personal story about how he used to catch grasshoppers to sell to hawkers such as Mr Ratana. The facilitators were really fluent in both Khmer and English, so they could translate all our questions to Mr Ratana and translate his answers back to us.My partner became quite addicted to crickets in specific after this rewarding experience. Even craving for crickets to go with wine! Now it's time for Backstreet to come up with a cricket catching course so I learn how to get most vital ingredient to fried crickets. :)

Excellent bracelet making. My friend and I are from Siem Reap. We had very FUN and interesting experience in bracelet making last weekend! The instructors were very friendly, skillful and structured. Also, staffs who came along with us also very helpful as well, show us around workshop and explain history. At the end, we have got bracelet home with our own designed! I would recommend you to try this course!

Delightful evening with Backstreet Academy!. After a tiring day at the temples, me and my partner stumbled onto Backstreet Academy's Khmer cocktail class and thought it might be a nice way to unwind the evening. We were not sure what to expect but decided to go anyway. We contacted them on the day itself and received a prompt response with a confirmation for 6 pm. Communication was not a problem and the location was easy to find. Once we arrived at the place, preparation had already been made and we soon got the course underway. The experience I must say was brilliant. Spices and alcohol mixed together to create a wide mix of cocktails. Some refreshing, some spicy and some simply twists on classics like the mojito and singapore sling. Nonetheless, every one of the cocktails we made delighted our senses. The aroma and the taste was unlike anything you would get out a of glass of cocktail. The instructor, charming and professional, was very knowledgeable and friendly too. Go to the temples, get a massage and end the evening with this inspiring experience!

Massage course. We went on themassage course. Everyone was very charmng and we really enjoyed our afternoon in the company of the massage team who clearly knew alot about the topic. However we think more work needs to go into the course which was more of a demonstration to show us a full cambodian body massage. Although interesting, it was too much to learn in a few hours and I would have no chance of repeating what I saw. That said I would recommend backstreet academy who clearly have thier heart in the right place and will do thier best for you.

Unforgettable one off experience- fear factor challenge. In one word, unmissable. If you get the chance I could not recommend this whole company highly enough We did both the horse riding and fear factor challenge in Siem Reap. The horse riding was very professional with the guide fluent in English and very helpful taking us around the town and rice fields for an hour. Fear factor challenge was a highlight with us being taught how to prepare, cook and eat tradional insects by one of the street sellers at his home. It was totally different to any cooking classes we had seen before and so much more authentic. The bugs were totally differerent to what i expected too, tarantulas now a firm favourite. The cook and translators were very knowledgeable and helpful and a good laugh too. Would definitely recommend this experience, great fun and a total one off.
